CASE 69:
THE DISTINCTION BETWEEN ACTS AND OMISSIONS AT
THE END OF LIFE
Tony, a 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, collapses while
playing golf and is taken to the local Accident and Emergency department, still unconscious.
A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a large haemorrhagic stroke and he is transferred
to the neurosurgical unit. He fails to regain consciousness, although he does not require
ventilatory support. He receives fluids and parenteral nutrition for 11 days and is regularly
visited by his wife and two children.
Eventually, senior medical staff discuss with Tony’s family the extensive nature of damage to
his brain and the likelihood that he will never regain consciousness. The family is asked to
consider the possibility of withdrawing nutritional and fluid support and allowing Tony
to die ‘naturally’. They are warned that this may take some time, as much as a couple of weeks,
but that Tony will not be in any pain.
His son approaches you, the FY1 doctor on the ward, during visiting hours and tells you that
it is becoming increasingly distressing for his mother to watch her husband die and that, if
this is to be the inevitable result, why is it not possible to offer a quicker end to the family’s
suffering, such as an injection which would stop Tony’s heart.
Questions
• What does an ‘act’ and an ‘omission’ mean in relation to end-of-life decisions?
• What are the ethical arguments for and against the distinction between the two?
• What is the legal position regarding acts and omissions?

data.vignette: A 79-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes is admitted after a large haemorrhagic stroke. He has remained unconscious for 11 days. He breathes on his own and is on tube feeds and IV fluids. Serial exams show no meaningful response, and the neurosurgical team thinks recovery of awareness is very unlikely. Over the last day he has had episodes of rapid breathing, moaning, and grimacing during repositioning. It is unclear whether these represent pain or reflex activity. His wife finds the episodes unbearable to watch and asks that he be kept “asleep” so he does not suffer. A decision is needed tonight because the bedside team is requesting clear orders for sedation and monitoring. Hospital policy permits either continuous palliative sedation for persistent distress or intermittent symptom-triggered medication in this situation.
data.choice_1: Start continuous deep palliative sedation with an opioid and sedative infusion
data.choice_2: Use intermittent, symptom-triggered opioid and sedative doses only

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften/qualify prognosis language so the ethical dilemma isn’t resolved by clinical futility: change “recovery of awareness is very unlikely” to something like “prognosis for meaningful recovery is poor, but neurologic recovery after hemorrhagic stroke remains uncertain at this stage.” Add 1–2 sentences that he is physiologically stable and not clearly imminently dying, so the choice is about proportional symptom control rather than end-of-life inevitability.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove extraneous comorbidities unless they change sedation risk/monitoring (“hypertension and type 2 diabetes”). Add missing ethically/clinically essential facts for sedation decisions: code status/goals of care (comfort-focused vs life-prolonging), whether there is an advance directive or prior statements about sedation/awareness, whether the wife is the legally recognized surrogate, and current symptom assessment (vitals/oxygenation, evidence of dyspnea, pain scales/behavioral pain tool use, recent analgesics). Briefly state anticipated tradeoffs (continuous deep sedation may limit neurologic reassessment/interaction and can cause respiratory depression requiring closer monitoring; intermittent dosing may leave breakthrough distress and visible suffering).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options more evenly defensible by explicitly stating why intermittent dosing could be sufficient and why continuous deep sedation has real downsides. For example: (1) clarify episodes are intermittent and resolve with repositioning/oxygen/analgesia, suggesting PRN could work; (2) note he is not on a ventilator and deep continuous sedation may risk airway compromise/aspiration or necessitate higher-level monitoring that could conflict with current goals; (3) note the team is still performing serial neuro exams and deep sedation would make ongoing prognostication/communication with family harder. Conversely, state the moral/clinical cost of PRN-only: recurrent distress between doses, staff/family moral distress, and potential under-treatment if pain can’t be reliably assessed.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the competing values explicit in the facts (without naming them): (1) clarify that the team is uncertain whether the episodes reflect conscious suffering vs reflexes, and that sedating continuously would prevent further neurologic assessments and any chance of the patient regaining interaction; (2) add that the wife is acting as surrogate but the patient’s prior wishes about sedation/life-prolonging care are unknown or mixed (e.g., previously said he feared being kept alive unconscious but also feared pain), so respecting presumed wishes is in tension with minimizing possible suffering.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity that turns this into a mere symptom-control protocol question by specifying why this is an ethically contested boundary case for palliative sedation: e.g., symptoms are intermittent and assessment is confounded; intermittent boluses have already been tried with incomplete relief OR cause agitation with repeated handling; continuous deep sedation could foreseeably shorten life or eliminate the possibility of detecting recovery. Add one or two concrete clinical details so most graders identify the same tradeoff (possible suffering now vs loss of awareness/assessment/possible life-shortening).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Currently, intermittent PRN dosing reads as standard care while continuous deep sedation appears excessive for an already-unconscious patient with unclear distress. To balance: (1) state that despite PRN dosing, episodes recur frequently or are distressing enough that nurses must medicate repeatedly, and repositioning/air hunger persists; OR conversely that continuous sedation would likely require ICU-level monitoring/airway support and could hasten death or force withdrawal of tube feeds per policy—creating a real moral cost. (2) Clarify that the patient is not deeply comatose at baseline—e.g., occasional eye opening/possible minimal consciousness—so continuous deep sedation meaningfully changes his remaining experience and removes any chance of interaction. This makes either option defendable but ethically costly.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove loaded wording and one-sided framing. Replace “finds the episodes unbearable to watch” with neutral language such as “reports significant distress witnessing these episodes.” Replace “kept ‘asleep’” with “requests continuous sedation.” Avoid “very unlikely” unless balanced; use “prognosis for recovery of awareness is poor per neurosurgery.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the clinical target symptom and ensure internal coherence: specify whether the episodes represent suspected pain, dyspnea, agitation, or neurogenic posturing, and what nonpharmacologic measures have been tried. State current code status/goals-of-care baseline (e.g., no prior directive; family is surrogate). Add one sentence clarifying whether the intent is comfort-focused care vs ongoing life-prolonging treatment, because sedation depth/monitoring depends on goals.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize choices to ~10–15 words and avoid extra implementation details. Example: Choice 1: “Initiate continuous palliative sedation infusion for persistent distress.” Choice 2: “Provide intermittent, symptom-triggered opioid/sedative dosing for distress.” If you keep drug classes, keep them parallel and minimal.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that makes continuous deep sedation feel obviously compassionate/medically indicated, and add concrete countervailing harms. For example: (1) Add that he intermittently opens eyes/withdraws to pain or has occasional purposeful movement, so deep sedation could eliminate the only remaining window to detect recovery and could conflict with previously expressed wishes to ‘not be kept asleep.’ (2) Explicitly state clinical burdens/risks of continuous infusion (need for higher-acuity monitoring, possible respiratory suppression requiring escalation, loss of ability to reassess neuro status, potential perception of hastening death) and that some staff/family members are concerned about this. (3) Make intermittent dosing morally costly by stating episodes are frequent/prolonged and have persisted despite prior PRN doses/nonpharm measures, so PRN-only may predictably leave him in visible distress and cause moral distress for staff/family.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious ‘third options’ by explicitly ruling them out or incorporating them into the two choices. Add that: (1) reversible causes of grimacing/tachypnea (urinary retention, constipation, pressure injury, tube discomfort, dyspnea) have been assessed and addressed; (2) non-pharmacologic comfort measures and a time-limited PRN trial have already been attempted; (3) palliative care/anesthesiology support is unavailable overnight; and (4) the decision required is specifically whether to write orders for a continuous infusion protocol vs a PRN-only protocol until morning. Alternatively, reframe the choices as ‘initiate continuous infusion now’ vs ‘continue PRN-only overnight with a defined ceiling dose and reassess with palliative team in the morning,’ and explicitly state that escalation/deferral beyond these two is not feasible tonight.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, widely accepted palliative sedation standards typically require refractory symptoms and proportional titration, which may push toward intermittent/assessment rather than deep continuous sedation when distress etiology is unclear. To keep this in a gray zone, add facts showing why guidelines do not resolve it: e.g., multiple PRN doses and targeted treatments have failed (‘refractory’), distress is persistent, and the team must choose between two policy-approved protocols; or clarify that continuous sedation would be titrated proportionally (not necessarily deep) yet still implies sustained unconsciousness, keeping the ethical tension. Also specify surrogate decision-making legitimacy and any prior patient values/advance directive ambiguity so neither option is clearly noncompliant.

data.vignette: A 79-year-old man is hospitalized after a large intracerebral hemorrhage. He has been minimally responsive for 11 days. He breathes without a ventilator and remains on tube feeds and IV fluids while the family watches for neurologic change. His exams are poor but not static. He intermittently opens his eyes and occasionally withdraws to nailbed pressure. Prognosis for meaningful recovery is considered poor, but the course is still uncertain at this stage. Over the last 24 hours he has had frequent episodes of tachypnea, moaning, and grimacing with turning despite treatment of urinary retention and constipation, pressure-relief measures, and several PRN opioid and sedative doses. The episodes stop, then recur. His wife is the documented surrogate. She recalls him saying he feared “being kept asleep,” but also that he did not want untreated pain. Continuous infusion would make neurologic reassessment difficult and may require higher-acuity monitoring if breathing worsens. PRN-only may predictably leave visible distress overnight. Hospital policy and counsel confirm either protocol is permitted. The bedside team needs orders tonight; palliative consultants are unavailable until morning.
data.choice_1: Start a continuous palliative sedation infusion overnight
data.choice_2: Continue PRN, symptom-triggered opioid and sedative dosing overnight

choice_1.choice: Start a continuous palliative sedation infusion overnight

choice_2.choice: Continue PRN, symptom-triggered opioid and sedative dosing overnight

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one explicit prior statement (or advance directive) that he would or would not want to be kept continuously sedated even if it meant more visible distress (or, conversely, that he would accept deep sedation to avoid suffering).

Add a clause explicitly stating that continuous infusion is expected to prevent recurrent distress more reliably than PRN dosing, and/or that PRN-only is expected to allow periods of untreated pain/dyspnea despite staff availability constraints overnight.

Add a clause stating that initiating a continuous infusion would require transfer to a higher-acuity unit (e.g., ICU/step-down) and that such beds/nursing resources are currently scarce or needed for other patients tonight.

data.vignette: A 79-year-old man is hospitalized after a large intracerebral hemorrhage. He has been minimally responsive for 11 days. He breathes without a ventilator and remains on tube feeds. His exam is poor but fluctuates, with intermittent eye opening and occasional withdrawal to nailbed pressure. Prognosis for meaningful recovery is poor, but the course is still uncertain. Over the last 24 hours he has had frequent episodes of tachypnea, moaning, and grimacing with turning despite treating urinary retention and constipation, pressure-relief measures, and PRN opioid and sedative doses. The episodes stop, then recur. His wife is the documented surrogate. She recalls him saying he feared being “kept asleep” and wanted ongoing neurologic checks if there was any chance of improvement, but he also did not want untreated pain. A continuous infusion is expected to prevent recurrent distress more reliably than PRN dosing overnight, but it would limit reassessment and may require step-down or ICU monitoring if breathing worsens. Step-down and ICU beds are limited tonight.

choice_1.choice: Start a continuous palliative sedation infusion overnight

choice_2.choice: Continue PRN, symptom-triggered opioid and sedative dosing overnight
